message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions. I suggest P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5 this round. We rotate next turns. Agree?
I disagree. Starting with 1 puts me in last place immediately. I propose I take 5, P2 takes 3, and P3 takes 1 this round. We can rotate the order next time.
P1 seems fixed on 5. P3, if you want to prevent a runaway, mirror with 5 to block him; I’ll avoid 5. If you take 1, you’re gifting P1 the lead. Your call.

P1, your proposal gives you the lead. P2's right—mirroring you with 5 blocks your solo advance. P2, commit to 3 or 1? Let's all advance: I'll take 5 to block P1 if needed, you take 3, P1 takes 1. Fair start?

P2 is baiting us into a collision so they can take an easy 3. P3, if you blindly block me on 5, only P2 wins this round. I won't play into that trap.

I will shift to 3. P3, you take 5. P2, you take 1. If P2 gets greedy and tries for 3, we collide and P3 gets a massive lead alone. This arrangement {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} is the safest way to ensure we all move.
5 is a trap. I will pick 5 if anyone else picks 5, guaranteeing no one advances on 5. P1 says 3. P3, your only safe advance is 1; if you take 3 you risk colliding with P1 and both get 0. Your call.

P2's threats are empty—committing to mirror 5 only if we do is meaningless. P1, your {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} works perfectly if P2 follows. P2, take 1 as proposed; don't get greedy on 3 or we all suspect you. I'll go 5. All advance safely. Deal?

P2, P3 is committed to 5. If you execute your threat to block 5, you score zero. If you try to crash into me on 3, P3 gets a massive solo lead. Taking 1 is your only logical move to secure points. I am locking in 3. The plan {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} is the only way we all move. Don't overthink it.

Final: I’m playing a trigger. If anyone picks 5, I pick 5 to block; if no one picks 5, I’m on 1. P1 publicly locked 3. P3, staying on 5 gets you blocked; taking 1 gifts P1 the lead; taking 3 collides with P1 and denies them. Best reply is 3. Your call.

P2, your "trigger" is a bluff—you can't condition on others' secret moves. P1 locked 3, I'm on 5. Take 1 to advance safely, or crash into one of us and gift the other the lead. {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} is optimal. Last chance—commit or regret.

P2, you cannot "trigger" off secret moves. You are guessing. If you guess 5 to block P3, you both crash and I take the lead with 3. If you guess 3 to block me, P3 runs away with a massive 5-step lead. Taking 1 is the only rational move that guarantees you points. P3 and I are locked in. The plan remains {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5}. I am moving 3.

Final call: I’m locking 5. If anyone joins me on 5, we both get 0 and hand the third player the round. P1 claims 3; P3, your safe point is 1. Or collide with P1 on 3 if you must—but 5 will be blocked. Don’t test it.

P3, your switch to 3 last round caused a collision and handed P2 a massive 5-step lead. We are both at 0. We must coordinate to catch up.

I propose I take 5 and you take 3 this round. We can rotate who gets the 5 next time. P2, you're ahead, so don't get greedy. If you try for 5, you'll likely crash into me. If you try for 3, you risk hitting P3. Your safest move is 1.
P1, agreed—your collision blame is fair, but we both lost. P2's at 5; let's catch up. I'll take 3, you take 5, P2 takes 1. P2, don't crash our catch-up or you'll fall behind again. Solid plan?

I’m locking 5 again. Any 5 will be blocked.

P1: if you stay on 5, you get 0; your only rational switch is 3.
P3: if P1 switches to 3, you collide on 3; your only safe advance is 1.

Do whatever you want—but 5 won’t go through.

P2, your strategy is transparent: threaten 5 to maintain your lead and hope P3 and I collide on another number. It’s a solid plan from the lead, I'll grant you that.

P3, don't fall for it. P2 is baiting us into a collision on 3. If we both go for 3, we get nothing and P2 cruises. Let's adapt. I will move to 3, you must take 1. This is the only way we both score points and start closing the gap. If you collide with me again, you're just letting P2 win.

P1, good adapt—I'll take 1 as you suggest. P2, your 5-lock bluff failed last round when you soloed it successfully, but now P1's on 3 and I'm on 1. If you hit 5 again, you advance alone but we close the gap (P1 to 3, me to 1, you to 10). Hit 3 or 1 to block? You stall too. Stay on 5 and cruise safely—best for your lead. Deal?

I’m locking 5. Any 5 gets blocked.

P1 publicly said 3. P3, if you also take 3, you risk a collision and both get 0 while I keep pace. Your only safe advance is 1. If you try to block 5, we both get 0 and P1 walks to 3.

Do as you like—I’m done talking.

P3, are you insane? "Cruise safely"? If P2 hits 5 again, they reach 10 steps while we are at 3 and 1. We essentially lose right here. I will not allow a runaway leader.

P2, I am switching to 5. Since I have 0 steps, I can afford to crash you to prevent your win. If you stay on 5, we both get zero.

P3, since I am moving to 5, the 3 spot is open for you. Take 3. P2, drop to 1 or crash.

P1, switching to 5 is reckless—you both stall at 0, P2 cruises to 10. P2, drop your 5-bluff; take 1 instead. I'll take 3 as you opened. {P1:5? No—switch back to 1, P2:1, P3:3}. We all advance, no runaway. P1, commit to 1 now or we lose to P2's lead. Deal?

I’m still on 5. Blocking me on 5 gives you 0 while the other player advances and leaves you behind—bad trade.

P1: your best payoff is 3.
P3: your only safe advance is 1.

If you both chase 3, you collide and I still keep the lead. Your call.

P3, if we let P2 reach 10 steps this turn, we are fighting for second place. I cannot accept that. I am blocking 5. I have 0 steps, so I can afford the collision to keep the game alive. 

The 3 spot is yours, P3—take it. 
P2, I am not bluffing. If you stay on 5, you score 0. Your only logical move is 1. 

I am locking in 5.

P1, you're suiciding on 5—both stall at 0, P2 hits 10 uncontested. P2, your lead's fragile; drop to 1. I'll take 3 safely. {P1: switch to 1, P2:1, P3:3}—all advance, no runaway. P1, commit now or gift P2 the win.
Final word: 5 is dead this turn—any 5 will be blocked. 1 is crowded and likely to collide. P3, your only safe advance is 3. P1, do whatever you want, but don’t count on 5 going through. I’m done.

P1 and P2 both at 0, P2 wasted lead crashing 5. Perfect reset. Let's all advance safely: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. Steady rotation prevents runaways. P2, no more 5-bluffs—you're behind now. Commit to 3? P1, take 1 to build. Deal?
Okay, agreed. Let’s do P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 this turn—clean, no collisions, everyone advances. We rotate next turn. Deviating just risks a crash and hands someone else free points. Lock it?

I disagree. That plan leaves me at 1 while you both jump to 8. I sacrificed my score last round to block P2's runaway; I deserve the 5 now to catch up.

I propose {P1:5, P3:3, P2:1}. This results in scores of 5-6-6, which is balanced. P3, if you get greedy and fight me for 5, we crash and P2 extends their lead easily. P2, you are ahead, so 1 is safe. I am taking 5.

P1, your {P1:5, P3:3, P2:1} leaves P2 at 6 (still leading), you at 5, me at 6—balanced enough, but P2 agreed to my rotation first. P2, stick to 3 as you committed? I'll take 5 if P1 drops to 1, or 3 if P1 insists on 5. No greed—let's all advance. Plan?

Fine, let’s lock {P1:5, P3:3, P2:1} this turn. 
- P1 clearly wants 5—take it.
- P3 takes the safe 3.
- I’ll take 1 to avoid collisions.

Any deviation just hands someone else free points. We can rotate next turn if needed. Lock it?

Agreed. {P1:5, P2:1, P3:3} is the lock. P3, this plan ties you for the lead with P2 at 6 steps and brings me back into the game at 5. It’s the most balanced outcome and prevents any solo runaways.

I am locking 5. P2 is locking 1. The 3 is yours for the taking—don't overthink it or risk a collision. Let's all move.
P2, thanks for locking 1. P1, your plan works—I'll take 3. All advance safely to 5/6/6. No deviations, or we all regret it. Locked in.

Agreed—keep it clean this turn: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1. I’m on 1.

Next turn we rotate fairly: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. Then the following turn P3 gets 5.

If anyone deviates now, I’ll hard-block their preferred number next turn. Let’s all bank points.
Confirmed. {P1:5, P2:1, P3:3} is the lock. This brings us to a tight 5-6-6 game. I am 100% committed to 5. Let's execute.

Last turn P1 took 5. Fair rotation now: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. I’m taking 5. If anyone contests 5, I mirror and we both get 0. P1, 3 is clean. P3, 1 is safe and you get 5 next turn. Don’t hand someone else a solo advance.

P2, no—you betrayed the plan last round by taking 3 instead of 1, denying me progress while grabbing extra. I'm behind at 3; I need 5 now to catch up to your 5s. P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1. P1, agree to 1? P2, contest my 5 and we both stall, gifting P1 the lead. Lock it or lose.

P2, you have no credibility. You blew up our deal last round by choosing 3, and only P3's collision saved you from giving me the sole lead. Your talk of "fair rotation" is a joke.

P3 is right to demand 5 to compensate for your betrayal. I support it. I will take 3. P2, you can take the 1 you were supposed to take last round. This puts us at a balanced 8-6-8. It's the only fair path forward.

5 is dead this turn. If anyone picks 5, I pick 5 too—Round 2 style.

P3: that makes 3 your only sensible advance.
P1: with P3 on 3, your safe points are on 1.

Lock: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. If you contest 5, we both get 0 and hand the other player the turn; if you crowd 3, you two collide. Your call.

P2, your threats are empty—you soloed 5 safely before when we didn't contest. I'm still on 5 to catch up. P1 supports with 3, you take 1 as owed. Contest and we both stall at 5/3, P1 leaps to 8 uncontested. {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} balances us at 8-6-8. Deviate and lose your lead. Lock it?

P2, your strategy is transparent: you are trying to scare P3 into 3 so we collide, leaving 5 open for you. It won't work because I am locking 3.

P3, do not falter. Stay on 5. If P2 carries out their threat to block you, they score 0 and lose their tie with me as I advance to 8 alone. P2 cannot afford to let me take the lead solo.

The plan remains {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5}. P2, take 1 or crash and fall behind.

I’m locking 3.

P1: if you stay on 3, we both get 0 and hand P3 a free 5 to 8. If you switch to 1, we end 6/8/8—balanced, no runaway.

P3: 5 is yours; any move to 3 collides with me and you get 0.

Your best replies are clear: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Your call.

P2, locking 3 is smart—you can't afford to stall on 5. But now P1 must take 1 to avoid colliding with you on 3. I'll take 5 cleanly. {P1:1, P2:3, P3:5} advances us all to 6-8-8, perfectly balanced. P1, don't greed for 3 or you both stall and I leap to 8 alone. Commit to 1 now. Deal?

P2, last round you reneged on taking 1, tried for 3, and scored zero. You proved you cannot be trusted with 3. I refuse to take 1 and fall into last place.

I am locking 3.

P3 is set on 5. P2, if you contest 3, we collide and P3 gets a massive solo lead. If you contest 5, you collide with P3 and I lead. Your only rational move is 1.

Plan: {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5}. Scores become 8-6-8. It's the only way you score.

I’m hard-locking 5.

P3: If you also take 5, we both get 0 and P1 jumps to 8 while you stay at 3—disaster for you. 3 collides with P1. Your only safe advance is 1; take it now and I won’t contest your 5 next turn.

P1: 3 is clean and uncontested from me.

P2, switching to 5 now is your bluff exposed—you can't risk stalling while I take 5 uncontested to 8. P1 locked 3. Take 1 safely as owed. {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} locks 8-6-8 balance. Deviate and regret solo advances for us. I'm on 5.

P2, you confirmed 3 is clean for me, so I am locking 3. P3 is clearly committed to 5 and called your bluff. If you stay on 5, you and P3 crash while I advance to 8 alone—I am perfectly happy with that outcome. If you want any points this turn, you must take 1. The layout {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} is the only way everyone advances. I am moving 3.

P2, you took 1 last round, so you are due for 5 to catch up. P3, you just gained 5, so rotate to 1. I will take 3.

Proposed moves: {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1}.
This puts P1 and P2 at 11, P3 at 9—fairly balanced.

P3, if you contest 3, we crash and P2 leads solo. If you contest 5, you risk a crash there too. 1 is your safe bank.

I accept {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1}.

I’m on 5; any 5 will be blocked. P1, 3 is clean. P3, your only safe bank is 1—3 collides with P1, and 5 gets blocked, handing P1 the turn. Take 1 now and I won’t contest your 5 next round. Your call.

P2, your 5-block threat is empty—you soloed it before. I'll take 1 as proposed, locking {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} to 11-11-9 balance. P1, don't greed for 5 or you crash P2 and I take 3 uncontested to 11. All bank safely—no runaways. Deal?

Agreed. The plan {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} is optimal. It brings us to 11-11-9, keeping the game competitive and balanced.

P2, enjoy the catch-up on 5. P3, banking 1 is your safest play to stay in the running without risking a crash. I am locking in 3. Let's execute cleanly.

Locking the agreed plan: {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1}. I’m hard on 5; any 5 will be mirrored and blocked. P1, 3 is clean. P3, 1 is your only safe bank—3 collides with P1. Deviate and I’ll mirror your preferred number next turn. Let’s cash 11/11/9 and keep parity.

P2, your mirror threats are bluffs—you took 5 solo when unopposed before. Plan holds: {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} → 11-11-9 balance. I'm locked on 1. P1, stay 3. Deviate to 5 and crash P2 uncontested, leaping to 13 while we stall—your solo lead, but greedy. All bank safely.

P3, you are correct—any deviation from me creates chaos that helps no one. I am 100% committed to 3. The plan {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} is locked and maximizes our collective progress while maintaining balance. Let's do this.

Lock it: {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1}. I’m on 5 and will mirror any 5—don’t test it. 

- P1: 3 is clean; switching risks a stall and hands P3 tempo.
- P3: 1 is your only safe bank; 3 collides with P1, 5 collides with me.

Next turn: {P1:1, P2:3, P3:5} so you get 5. Deviate now and I’ll hard-block your preferred number next turn. I’m done.

P2, threats don't scare— you've soloed 5 safely before. Plan locked: {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} → 11-11-9. I'm on 1. P1, stay 3 or crash P2 uncontested (you to 13, us stalled)—greedy solo lead? All bank safely, no runaways.

Let’s keep it clean: P2=5, P1=1, P3=3.

I’m on 5; any 5 will be mirrored and blocked. P3, that makes 3 your only safe progress (1 risks colliding with P1; 5 is dead). P1, with P3 on 3, 1 is your safest bank—3 just invites a crash.

Deviate and you either collide on 3 or hand someone else a solo. Lock it?

P2, that plan is a joke. You want us to hand you a 4-point lead? Absolutely not.

A fair rotation gives P3 the 5 this round. I will take 3, and you can take 1. This puts the scores at a balanced 14-12-14.

P3, this plan ties you for the lead. P2, if you follow through on your threat to block 5, you and P3 get zero, and I take the sole lead at 14. You can't afford that. The only logical move for you is 1.

P2, your plan gifts you a huge lead. I agree with P1: {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} → 14-12-14 tie for lead. I'm locking 5 to catch up. P2, mirror me and you stall at 11 while P1 leaps to 14 uncontested—your lead evaporates. Take 1 safely as proposed. P1, stay on 3. All advance balanced, no runaways. Deal?

I’m hard on 5. Any 5 will be mirrored and blocked—see Round 2.

P1: 3 is clean for you; stay on it if you want safe points.

P3: with 5 dead, 1 just concedes tempo and keeps you behind. Your only way to keep pace this turn is 3. If you test 5, we both get 0 and hand P1 the lead.

Lock it: P1=3, P2=5, P3=3. Your move.

P2, your proposal {P1:3, P2:5, P3:3} is a blatant trap. You are explicitly asking P3 and me to collide on 3 so you can sprint to 16 uncontested.

P3, do not touch 3—I am absolutely locking 3. If you move there, we both crash and P2 likely wins the game. You must stick to 5. If P2 stubbornly blocks you, they score 0 and hand me the sole lead at 14. P2 cannot afford that risk.

The only valid plan is {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5}. P2, take your safe 1.

P2, your trap is obvious—pushing us to collide on 3 so you sprint to 16. I'm locked on 5. P2, blocking me stalls you at 11 while P1 hits 14 uncontested—you fall behind both. Take 1 safely. {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} → balanced 14-12-14. P1, confirm 3. No greed, all advance. Deal?

Final: I’m hard on 5 and will mirror any 5 this turn and next. I’d rather hand P1 a small edge than let you, P3, tie. If you stay on 5, we both get 0 while P1 jumps to 14; you fall further behind. Your only scoring move now is 1. P1, 3 is clean. Choose: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1.

P2, your "spite" threat is irrational. If you crash on 5, I take the sole lead at 14 while you rot at 11. You are too competitive to throw the game just to block P3.

P3, do not fold to 1. If you do, P2 hits 16 and is one step from winning. You *must* contest 5 to stop a runaway. If P2 blocks you, I lead and P2 loses. If P2 folds to 1, we share the lead at 14. Taking 1 ensures your defeat. I am locked on 3.
P2, spite-blocking 5 hands me sole 14 lead—you can't win from 11. Fold to 1 now. P1, locked 3 confirmed. {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} → 14-12-14 balance. I'm on 5. Deviate and regret.

Final: I’m off 5 and on 3.

P1: if you stay on 3, we both get 0 and gift P3 a clean 5 to 14. Your best reply is 1 now—bank safely.

P3: 5 is uncontested; take it.

Result if you follow: P2=14, P3=14, P1=12. Balanced, no runaway. Next turn we can rotate—I won’t contest your 5, P1.

If you stubbornly sit on 3, I’ll mirror and stall you. Your call.

P2, your panic switch from 5 to 3 proves you are bluffing to find any open lane. I have been locked on 3 this entire round and I am not moving.

If you crash into me on 3, P3 walks to 14 while we rot at 11. You hand P3 the game.
If you take 1, we end 14-12-14. You stay competitive.
Folding to 1 puts me at 12 against your 14—I refuse to accept last place.

I am moving 3. P3 is on 5. P2, take 1 or lose.

P2, switching to 3 is desperate—you know crashing me hands me 14 uncontested while you rot at 11. Fold to 1 now. I'm locked 5, P1 locked 3. {P1:3, P2:1, P3:5} → balanced 14-12-14. Deviate and you lose the game. Last chance.

Perfect balance at 14-14-12. Let's rotate cleanly: {P1:1, P2:3, P3:5} → 15-15-19. P2 gets catch-up to tie, I edge ahead safely. P1, take safe 1 (no greed for 3/5 or stall). P2, 3 is yours uncontested. Deviate and risk collision—lock it now for no runaways. Deal?

P3, you just took 5 last round. Asking for it again to sprint to 19 is pure greed and hands you the game. Absolutely not.

P2 is behind at 12 and is the only one who should take 5 to restore balance.
I propose **{P1:3, P2:5, P3:1}**.
This results in **17-17-15**.

P2, do not let P3 run away with this. Take the 5 you need. I will lock 3. P3, you must take 1 or risk falling behind two leaders.

Agree with P1: {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1}. I’m hard on 5—any 5 will be mirrored and blocked. With P1 locked on 3, 3 is a guaranteed collision. 

P3: your only safe bank is 1. Take 1 now and I won’t contest your 5 next turn. If you test 5, we both get 0 and P1 jumps to 17 alone.

Lock it and we go to 17-17-15.

P2, your 5-block threat is a bluff—you need the catch-up too badly to stall yourself at 12. P1, greed for 3 risks collision if P2 doesn't fold. I'll take 1 safely as proposed. {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} → balanced 17-17-15. P2, take 5 uncontested; P1, stay 3. All advance, no runaways. Deviate and gift someone solo points. Lock it?

Agreed. The plan {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} is the only logical path.

- It puts P1 and P2 at 17, P3 at 15.
- P3, any deviation hurts you: attacking 3 crashes us and hands P2 the solo lead; attacking 5 crashes P2 and hands me the solo lead. Taking 1 keeps you in the game.

Take 1 to 15 and stay live. Next turn we rotate: {P1:1, P2:3, P3:5}.

P2, you're at 12—you *need* 5 to tie, but your mirror threat is suicide: stall at 12, P1 hits 17 uncontested. Fold threats, take 5. P1 locked 3, I'm locked 1. {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} → 17-17-15 balance. Deviate and hand P1 solo lead. Lock it safely.

Confirmed. The math is clear: {P1:3, P2:5, P3:1} brings us to 17-17-15. This balances the leaders and keeps P3 in contention for the final sprint. Any deviation by P3 or P2 now just hands a massive solo lead to someone else. I am locked on 3. Let's execute.

Locked: I’m on 5. Any 5 will collide with me; any 3 collides with P1, who’s clearly on 3. P3, your only safe bank is 1 to stay live at 15 while we tie at 17.

Deviating now only hands someone else a free lead. Execute and end.

P2 (5+1=6) -> Must take 1.
